You're right, but Overwatch: Return is a brand new first-person shooter developed by Activision Blizzard. Now I can earn 60 gold coins every week I play Overwatch, which is about 240 gold coins per month, that is, an income level of 7.2 yuan per month in real life, which is converted to 31 weeks, that is, 7 months, I can buy an ordinary Overwatch gold skin, although Overwatch 1 can have a chance to open as long as 1000 gold coins are upgraded back to the box. But it has surpassed the level of the vast majority of people in China (including you), which is the pride of Overwatch to me. ow has no obligation to give you what you want, it is just a game, to bring you happiness, but also according to your small temper? Even if he does not let you play, he is not wrong, remember ow does not owe you, maybe we all owe Blizzard a thank you, Blizzard spent a lot of energy and money to produce ow2, and finally open to players for free, you are still not satisfied, remember that we choose ow, not ow choose us, you can retreat if you feel bad. Blizzard and ow do not owe us, but we owe Blizzard and ow a thank you, as well as the production team for more than two years of hard work, instead of criticizing and asking the official to refund. If you think what I said is wrong, you must not understand the gold content of summer 2016.

cat

Once upon a time, I had a cat, I had ten dollars, I would buy it food for eight dollars, bathe it often, and it was very sticky to me.

Later, I took it out to play, passers-by thought it was cute, they fed it cat food, ham sausage, I was very unhappy because it was mine. I wanted to carry it home, but he broke away from me and meowed at the person who gave it good food, I hugged him a few times and he didn't go with me, and scratched me, so I turned around and left.....

Later, I came across it by chance on the road, and it was dirty. Passers-by will only give it good food and play with it, but they will not take it home and bathe it. It saw me and followed me home, I shut it out, it meowed outside the door, it was very uncomfortable,
but I wouldn't want it anymore
.

As an Overwatch player, I initially held higher expectations for the gaming experience of Overwatch 2, encompassing both PvP and PvE aspects. However, the current state of PvE, with the removal of the previous skill tree and the requirement for additional payment for what seems like an advanced version of the "Archives" missions, coupled with the lackluster PvP experience, leads me to believe that this fundamentally isn't Overwatch 2. It falls short of even being comparable to the original Overwatch; it might be more fittingly referred to as Overwatch 1/2 or Overwatch 0.5.

In the 5v5 mode, the tank heroes within the team counter each other during switching, akin to a "rock-paper-scissors" game. This situation renders the tactical choices within the game singular and uninteresting, as players are compelled to adjust their hero selection based on the opponent's choices to gain an advantage, rather than selecting their preferred heroes. However, this counterplay dynamic could also result in the game battles feeling monotonous and dull. If one side's tank is countered and a hero isn't switched in time, it can make the entire game challenging to manage, with scarcely any chance of victory. This parallels the "rock-paper-scissors" phenomenon, highlighting the influence of hero selection on the game's outcome.

Yet, in the 6v6 mode, due to the presence of dual tanks, the counterplay relationship between tanks is less conspicuous. Dual tanks also offer improved protection and output conditions for damage and support heroes, broadening the range of strategic choices within the game. Furthermore, the 6v6 mode grants players the opportunity to explore a wider array of tactical combinations, extending beyond the tank-to-tank interactions confined to the 5v5 mode.

Moreover, the impact of game music and details on the gaming experience is substantial. Certain skins in Overwatch 1 possess unique effects and sounds that greatly enhance the game's allure. However, in Overwatch 2, some of these elements seem to have been removed or diminished, which is perplexing. Personally, I favor the music of the first installment, as it effectively conveys a sense of gravity and solemnity prior to matches. In Overwatch 2, there is a prevailing sense of fast-food-like and somewhat inexpensive aesthetics to the music, although undoubtedly there will be other players who appreciate it. Retaining the original Overwatch music and configuring it as an optional mode could enable players to savor the musical ambiance in accordance with their preferences. Overwatch 2's footsteps also bear similarities to the overwhelming auditory impact of Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2019; though discernible with a higher player count, they still remain chaotic. Weapon sounds have been modified to a lesser extent, such as Blizzard's claim to employ actual firearm recordings during development. While Blizzard indeed recorded these sounds, Soldier 76's final gunshot didn't utilize authentic firearm sounds, instead resembling that of a helicopter. Ana's voice sounds peculiar, and McCree's voice is unconventional, bordering on explosive. The only sound that has been adequately improved, in my view, is Widowmaker's firearm noise.

In terms of social interaction, I believe that Overwatch 2 should reintegrate the team-finding feature from Overwatch 1, facilitating the process for players to locate suitable teammates and enhancing social connections. Furthermore, preserving the loot box feature from Overwatch 1 remains valuable. Even though Overwatch 2 has introduced a battle pass, the delight derived from obtaining items through loot boxes can still enhance the gaming experience and sustain a sense of anticipation for players.

Addressing the game's user interface, while improvements are discernible in this update, Overwatch 2's UI design still lags. Notably, character without upscaling to high-definition resolution. Additionally, the bold "Microsoft YaHei" Chinese font appears unappealing, and the UI effects in Overwatch 2 are excessively vivid and dazzling, occasionally causing Mercy's blue-yellow beams to obstruct the player's front view entirely. When subjected to substantial damage, an excess of red obscures the player's field of vision, hindering clear perception. These issues do not exist in Overwatch 1, where black and light yellow indicators are prominent without obstructing the view. Furthermore, Ana's healing feedback is noticeably inferior compared to before.

Additionally, I hope that the Chinese Overwatch server will return soon.

In conclusion, it appears to be more of an Overwatch 0.5 combined with an "Archives" 1.5 expansion rather than a genuine Overwatch 2.
